evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief
evidence.text: Plaintiffs Leobardo Moreno Galvez, Jose Luis Vicente Ramos, and Angel de Jesus Muñoz Olivera are immigrant youth under the age of 21 who have applied for Special Immigrant Juvenile Status (SIJS), a form of humanitarian relief that provides vulnerable youth with a path to long-term legal status. Congress provided SIJS for children and youth under the age of 21 who obtain specific factual determinations by a state court with jurisdiction over their custody. Namely, the state court must find that (1) reunification with one or both of the youth’s parents is not viable due to abuse, neglect, abandonment, or similar basis under state law, and (2) it is not in the youth’s best interest to be returned to their country of origin.

extracted.value: Plaintiffs Leobardo Moreno Galvez, Jose Luis Vicente Ramos, and Angel de Jesus Muñoz Olivera are immigrant youth under 21 who applied for Special Immigrant Juvenile Status (SIJS) after Washington state courts found reunification with parents not viable due to abuse/neglect and it's not in their best interest to return to home country.

evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief
evidence.text: On behalf of themselves and other similarly situated youth, Plaintiffs bring this class action to challenge the federal government’s policy of refusing to adjudicate their SIJS petitions in accordance with the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA). The government’s blanket denial of SIJS for youth who obtain predicate SIJS orders after turning 18 but before the age of 21 violates the controlling statute and regulations.

extracted.value: USCIS denied SIJS applications for youth who obtained SIJS orders from Washington state courts after turning 18, violating statutory requirements and denying lawful status to vulnerable youth.

evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief
evidence.text: Specifically, the VYG statute 'grants the superior courts jurisdiction to make judicial determinations regarding the custody and care of . . . an unmarried person under twenty-one years of age.' Id. § 13.90.901(1)(a) (citing the INA’s definition of 'child,' 8 U.S.C. § 1101(b)); see also id. § 13.90.010(6) (defining 'vulnerable youth' as 'an individual who has turned eighteen years old, but who is not yet twenty-one years old').

extracted.value: Washington state courts have authority under RCW § 13.90.901 to issue SIJS findings for 18-20 year olds via Vulnerable Youth Guardianship (VYG) proceedings, including appointing guardians and making custody determinations.
